stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on level design and asset creation for Course 15, a retro-futuristic space level. Key activities included creating a flying car parking lot platforming section, designing and discarding an antenna-climbing mechanic, brainstorming a gramophone with piano-key stairs, and modeling a new collectible based on a 1950s CRT television. He also discussed team collaboration, future plans for a Steam release, and his game design philosophies.

development_findings.summary: During level design, Kaze decided to add a climbable piano key staircase to the side of a giant gramophone, embracing a whimsical and unconventional design choice.
development_findings.quote: That's just the type of schizophrenic thinking you need to be in a game.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle for the game is to keep the player's moveset as close to the standard Mario 64 movement as possible, influencing decisions like making flying cars into static platforms rather than drivable vehicles.
development_findings.quote: I don't like to take the base Mario 64 movement away from the player too much.

development_findings.summary: The hub world is planned to be the entirety of Yoshi's Island, designed to be the 'most alive-feeling hub of all time' and filled with more secrets than the original game.

Player feedback from a beta test led to a revision of the dive move. An initial attempt to remove directional control was rejected by testers, leading to a compromise where changing direction is possible but results in a loss of speed.
development_findings.quote: I have tried removing it... And people hated it. They completely hated it. So I made it so you can change the direction when you lose your speed now.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is cautious about accepting help from volunteer artists who lack experience with N64 development, as the technical limitations often require extensive training that negates the help offered.
development_findings.quote: I'm a little worried. I'm gonna have to spend so much time teaching him that he ends up costing more time than he saves, you know.

development_findings.summary: The game relies on significant custom engine optimizations, meaning later levels are not compatible with the standard Super Mario 64 engine and would not run correctly.
development_findings.quote: The later levels are made with the new engine optimizations in mind. So those would obviously not run fine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is replacing existing collectible models with a new retro-futuristic CRT television design provided by contributor Bruno Gadsen.
Kaze encountered a crash on real hardware caused by too many collision surfaces ('surface nodes') in one area, a common N64 limitation he had to design around.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed he intentionally isolated himself during his four years of university to focus completely on his work, acknowledging it was detrimental to his mental health.
context_findings.quote: I, on purpose, just didn't go out to meet people. Because I wanted to spend all my time working. That is not good for your mental health. And I don't recommend anyone does that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering an official Steam release of the game, which would require replacing all Nintendo assets and code to avoid legal issues.
context_findings.quote: I'm not just going to release a Mario game on Steam. That would literally be insanity.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is hesitant to use Kickstarter for funding due to a fear and lack of understanding of how sales tax laws apply to crowdfunding.
context_findings.quote: I'm scared of using Kickstarter and because of sales tax loss. I don't understand how they work with Kickstarter and I'm kind of scared of getting completely fucked.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the hub world is the most critical part of a 3D platformer, responsible for tying the game together and being the primary reason for Mario 64's success.
context_findings.quote: The hub world is I think the only reason Mario 64 was famous, popular. If Mario 64 hadn't had a hub world, I don't think anyone would have liked the game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a belief in a future of human-computer cyborgs and stated he would personally get brain enhancements to not be 'left behind'.
context_findings.quote: I think eventually we will all have computer enhanced bodies and we will eventually no longer be human... I definitely would take brain enhancements. I'm not going to be behind.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discussed the economic differences between Canada and his home country of Germany, concluding that Germany's social systems and taxes would make it more financially viable for him to not have a job.
context_findings.quote: If I lived in Germany and I was only ROM hacking, I would make more money if I just did ROM hack. Like, it would be cheaper for me to live in Germany if I didn't work than if I did work.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided critical feedback on a boss concept, finding it too 'cryptic'. He then proposed a new idea that Kaze has agreed to.
biobak.quote: I was talking to Biobak about the Yoshi boss idea that we had... and I agree with what he said about it being maybe a little cryptic and he brought up a few other ideas that maybe we're going to do.

biobak.summary: Biobak's new boss concept involves a creature called 'Octoyoshi' that attacks from black holes, requiring the player to enter its mouth to attack internal weak points.
biobak.quote: His idea was, wait one second... you maybe have to like jump into his mouth and like destroy the tumors inside and I think that works.

biobak.summary: Biobak is currently working on the graphical and design rework for Course 2.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's wife, is contributing art to the project; she drew designs for the Shy Guy NPCs that will be in the flying cars.

key_stories.title: The Steam Release Plan
key_stories.summary: Kaze discussed the possibility of releasing the game on Steam. He detailed the necessary steps to avoid legal trouble with Nintendo, which includes a complete overhaul of all assets and code, effectively creating a new, original game based on the project's framework.
key_stories.challenge: A potential path for giving the project a life beyond the ROM hacking scene and potentially monetizing it.
key_stories.process: Kaze outlined the plan to leverage the static recompilation project to create a standalone game. This would involve replacing Mario's character model and code, all other Nintendo assets, and the remaining proprietary engine code.
key_stories.outcome: A Steam release is a serious consideration for the future of the project, but Kaze is fully aware of the immense work required to make it legally distinct from Nintendo's IP.
key_stories.key_quote: Obviously, I would replace all Nintendo assets and would kick out the last bit of Nintendo code as well. I'm not just going to release a Mario game on Steam. That would literally be insanity.

key_stories.title: Redesigning the 'Cryptic' Boss
key_stories.summary: A collaborative effort between Kaze and Biobak led to a significant redesign of a key boss. After Biobak identified the original concept as too 'cryptic,' he pitched a new, more tangible idea of an 'Octoyoshi' that players would fight both externally and internally, which Kaze enthusiastically adopted.
key_stories.challenge: The team's initial idea for a major boss fight was conceptually weak and risked being confusing for players.
key_stories.process: Kaze discussed the initial boss concept with Biobak, the graphics artist. Biobak identified the idea as 'cryptic' and proposed an alternative where the boss attacks from black holes and the player must enter its mouth to damage it.
key_stories.outcome: The team now has a much stronger, more concrete boss concept, nicknamed 'Octoyoshi,' which Kaze has approved and intends to implement.
key_stories.key_quote: I agree with what he said about it being maybe a little cryptic and he brought up a few other ideas that maybe we're going to do... you maybe have to like jump into his mouth and like destroy the tumors inside and I think that works.

key_stories.title: The Dive Mechanic Compromise
key_stories.summary: Kaze's attempt to 'fix' Mario's dive mechanic illustrates his iterative, feedback-driven design process. His initial, drastic change was rejected by beta testers, forcing him to find a creative compromise that satisfied both his design sensibilities and player expectations.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to alter the game's dive mechanic, which he felt was too forgiving, but risked alienating players accustomed to the original feel.
key_stories.process: Kaze first implemented a version where directional control during a dive was completely removed. After beta testers unanimously rejected this change, he iterated on the design, creating a version that balanced his design goal with player feedback.
key_stories.outcome: A new, compromised dive mechanic is now in the game, where players can change direction but lose their momentum. This change was accepted by the community.
key_stories.key_quote: I have tried removing it so that you can't really change direction. And this was in the course 1 beta test thing. And people hated it. They completely hated it.
